#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=THE BARROOM
#Text=Phil did not leave the boat .
#Text=He lingered in the cabin until the passengers were seated , and after the boat was again under way began to play .
#Text=This time , however , he was not as fortunate as before .
#Text=While in the midst of a tune one of the men employed on the boat entered the cabin .
#Text=At times he would not have interfered with him , but he happened to be in ill humor , and this proved unfortunate for Phil .
#Text=“ Stop your noise , boy , ” he said .
#Text=Phil looked up .
#Text=“ May I not play ? ”
#Text=“ No ; nobody wants to hear you . ”
#Text=The young fiddler did not dare to disobey .
#Text=He saw that for the present his gains were at an end .
#Text=However , he had enough to satisfy the rapacity of the padrone , and could afford to stop .
#Text=He took a seat , and waited quietly till the boat landed .
#Text=One of the lady passengers , as she passed him on her way out of the cabin , placed ten cents in his hand .
#Text=This led him to count up his gains .
#Text=He found they amounted to precisely two dollars and fifty cents .
#Text=“ I need not play any more , ” he thought .
#Text=“ I shall not be beaten to-night . ”
#Text=He found his seat so comfortable , especially after wandering about the streets all day , that he remained on the boat for two more trips .
#Text=Then , taking his violin under his arm , he went out on the pier .
#Text=It was half-past seven o’clock .
#Text=He would like to have gone to his lodging , but knew that it would not be permitted .
#Text=In this respect the Italian fiddler is not as well off as those who ply other street trades .
#Text=Newsboys and bootblacks are their own masters , and , whether their earnings are little or great , reap the benefit of them themselves .

#Text=They can stop work at six if they like , or earlier ; but the little Italian musician must remain in the street till near midnight , and then , after a long and fatiguing day , he is liable to be beaten and sent to bed without his supper , unless he brings home a satisfactory sum of money .
#Text=Phil walked about here and there in the lower part of the city .
#Text=As he was passing a barroom he was called in by the barkeeper .
#Text=“ Give us a tune , boy , ” he said .
#Text=It was a low barroom , frequented by sailors and a rough set of customers of similar character .
#Text=The red face of the barkeeper showed that he drank very liberally , and the atmosphere was filled with the fumes of bad cigars and bad liquor .
#Text=The men were ready for a good time , as they called it , and it was at the suggestion of one of them that Phil had been invited in .
#Text=“ Play a tune on your fiddle , you little ragamuffin , ” said one .
#Text=Phil cared little how he was addressed .
#Text=He was at the service of the public , and what he chiefly cared for was that he be paid for his services .
#Text=“ What shall I play ? ” he asked .
#Text=“ Anything , ” hiccoughed one .
#Text=“ It ’s all the same to me .
#Text=I do n’t know one tune from another . ”
#Text=The young fiddler played one of the popular airs of the day .
#Text=He did not undertake to sing , for the atmosphere was so bad that he could hardly avoid coughing .
#Text=He was anxious to get out into the street , but he did not wish to refuse playing .
#Text=When he had finished his tune , one of those present , a sailor , cried , “ That ’s good .
#Text=Step up , boys , and have a drink . ”
#Text=The invitation was readily accepted by all except Phil .
#Text=Noticing that the boy kept his place , the sailor said , “ Step up , boy , and wet your whistle . ”
#Text=Phil liked the weak wines of his native land , but he did not care for the poisonous decoctions of be found in such places .
#Text=“ I am not thirsty , ” he said .
#Text=“ Yes , you are ; here , give this boy a glass of brandy . ”
#Text=“ I do not want it , ” said Phil .
#Text=“ You wo n’t drink with us , ” exclaimed the sailor , who had then enough to be quarrelsome .
#Text=“ Then I ’ll make you ; ” and he brought down his fist so heavily upon the counter as to make the glasses rattle .
#Text=“ Then I ’ll make you .
#Text=Here , give me a glass , and I ’ll pour it down his throat . ”
#Text=The fiddler was frightened at his vehemence , and darted to the door .
#Text=But the sailor was too quick for him .
#Text=Overtaking Phil , he dragged him back with a rough grasp , and held out his hand for the glass .
#Text=But an unexpected friend now turned up .
#Text=“ Oh , let the boy go , Jack , ” said a fellow sailor .
#Text=“ If he do n’t want to drink , do n’t force him . ”
#Text=But his persecutor was made ugly by his potations , and swore that Phil should drink before he left the barroom .
#Text=“ That he shall not , ” said his new friend .
#Text=“ Who is to prevent it ? ” demanded Jack , fiercely .
#Text=“ I will . ”
#Text=“ Then I ’ll pour a glass down your throat , too , ” returned Jack , menacingly .
#Text=“ No need of that .
#Text=I am ready enough to drink .
#Text=But the boy sha n’t drink , if he do n’t want to . ”
#Text=“ He shall ! ” retorted the first sailor , with an oath .

#Text=Still holding Phil by the shoulder with one hand , with the other he took a glass which had just been filled with brandy ; he was about to pour it down his throat , when the glass was suddenly dashed from his hand and broke upon the floor .
